resources.string: Identify pests from images to prevent early crop damage
Advanced AI-powered pest detection for agricultural protection

Welcome to SPIM. Our advanced AI helps you monitor, detect, and count pests in real-time to ensure your harvest stays healthy.
Take photos of pests for instant identification
Advanced machine learning for accurate pest detection

Works completely offline with local database

Need help again? Tap this icon anytime to restart this guide.

Small, pear-shaped, soft-bodied insects that suck sap from plant tissues. They cluster on the undersides of leaves and new growth. They secrete a sticky substance called \'honeydew,\' which leads to black sooty mold fungus and attracts ants.
Stage 1: Egg (Overwintering)\nIn autumn, eggs are laid on branches to survive the winter and hatch the following spring.
Stage 2: Nymph\nYoung aphids hatch or are born alive. They look like tiny adults and molt several times to reach maturity rapidly.
Stage 3: Wingless Adult (Summer Cycle)\nDuring the growing season, females are usually wingless and give birth to live young (viviparous) without mating, creating explosive population growth.
Stage 4: Winged Adult (Migration)\nWhen the colony becomes overcrowded, winged adults develop. These fly to new plants to start new colonies.
Predators: Lady beetles (Ladybugs) and their larvae, Green Lacewing larvae (often called \'aphid lions\'), and Hoverfly larvae.
Parasitoids: Tiny parasitic wasps (like Aphidius species) turn aphids into crusty, bronze-colored \'mummies.\'
Water Sprays: Blasting plants with a strong stream of water physically knocks aphids off; they often cannot climb back up.
Nitrogen Management: Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer, which creates the lush, tender growth that aphids love.
Reflective Mulches: Silver or aluminum-colored mulches can confuse aphids and repel them from landing on plants.

This refers to the family Chrysomelidae (which includes Flea Beetles and Cucumber Beetles). They are often metallic or brightly colored. Adults chew \'shotholes\' (small round holes) in leaves, while larvae may feed on roots or skeletonize leaves.
Stage 1: Egg\nClusters of eggs are laid in the soil or on the undersides of leaves.
Stage 2: Larva (Feeding Stage)\nWorm-like larvae hatch and feed voraciously on roots or foliage.
Stage 3: Pupa (Transformation)\nThe larvae drop to the soil to enter a resting stage called the pupa, where they transform into their adult form.
Stage 4: Adult (Reproduction)\nBeetles emerge to feed and reproduce. They often hibernate (overwinter) in leaf litter to survive the cold before laying eggs again.
Parasitoids: Parasitic wasps (such as Microctonus species) lay eggs inside the adult beetles.
Entomopathogenic Nematodes: Microscopic worms applied to the soil that hunt and kill the soil-dwelling larval stages.
Fungi: Beauveria bassiana can infect both adults and larvae.
Trap Crops: Plant a highly attractive crop (like mustard for flea beetles) near the main crop to lure pests away, then destroy the pests on the trap crop.
Floating Row Covers: Use white fabric covers immediately after planting to physically block adults from reaching the crop.
Sanitation: Remove crop debris and weeds at the end of the season to remove overwintering shelter for adults.

Also known as \'Grouse Locusts\' (Family Tetrigidae), these are very small (less than 20mm), dark-colored insects. They are easily distinguished by their pronotum (the shield-like plate behind the head), which extends all the way back over the abdomen, often looking like a long tail.

Why they are beneficial: Unlike pest grasshoppers, Pygmy Grasshoppers generally do not eat crops or garden plants. They are detritivores and algae-eaters. They are beneficial because they contribute to nutrient cycling and soil health by breaking down organic matter.
Diet (What they eat): They primarily feed on algae, moss, lichens, and decomposing organic matter (detritus) found in moist soil or mud.
Note: They are not predators; they do not eat other insects or pests. Their beneficial role is environmental (cleaning up detritus) rather than predatory.
Stage 1: Egg\nEggs are laid in mud, moist soil, or moss.
Stage 2: Nymph (Feeding Stage)\nNymphs hatch and immediately begin feeding on algae and detritus. They look like smaller versions of the adult.
Stage 3: Adult (Overwintering)\nAdults are distinguished by their long pronotum. Many overwinter as adults, allowing them to be active near water or mud banks very early in the spring.

These grasshoppers (Subfamily Gomphocerinae) are identified by their faces, which slant backward toward the body, and their pointed heads. They are primary pests of grasses, grains, and rangeland crops. They chew on leaves and stems, often stripping plants entirely during heavy infestations.
Stage 1: Egg (Overwintering)\nFemales lay \'pods\' of eggs in the soil during late summer or fall, which remain in the ground throughout the winter.
Stage 2: Nymph (Feeding Stage)\nIn spring, wingless nymphs hatch. They resemble small adults and pass through about 5 growth stages (instars) over 30‚Äì50 days.
Stage 3: Adult (Reproduction)\nFully winged adults emerge in summer to feed, mate, and lay the next generation of egg pods.
Pathogens: Nosema locustae is a protozoan bait that insecs grasshoppers and reduces their feeding and reproduction (slow-acting). The fungus Beauveria bassiana is also effective.
Predators: Natural predators include blister beetle larvae (which eat grasshopper eggs), birds, and spiders.
Tillage: Tilling the soil in late fall or early spring destroys egg pods and exposes them to predators.
Trap Strips: Leave strips of unmowed green vegetation to attract grasshoppers, then treat only those strips to reduce chemical use.
Weed Control: Eliminate weeds (like kochia or thistle) along field borders where nymphs often hatch and start feeding.
